Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Light-driven biocatalysts for the selective functionalization of substrate C-H bonds

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Cheruzel, 1509924

This proposal was co-funded by the Systems and Synthetic Biology program, Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences; the Chemistry of Life Processes Program, Division of Chemistry, and the Biocatalysis program of the Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems Division.

Biocatalysis has emerged as an important environmentally friendly route for the production of green and sustainable chemicals. Among candidate biocatalysts, cytochrome P450s are of great interest due to their synthetic potential in the selective oxidation of unactivated C-H bonds, using molecular dioxygen and two reducing equivalents. The proposed work will expand the capability of this class of enzymes for the production of specific chemicals in a sustainable way and with selectivity not readily obtainable with conventional chemistry. The work will be done by undergraduate students at San Jose State University (SJSU), a predominantly undergraduate minority-serving institution located in the heart of the Silicon Valley.

Specifically, this RUI award supports the optimization of efficient light-driven hybrid P450 biocatalysts. This class of enzyme is, however, still underused in biotechnological applications due to the requirement for an electron providing reductase and an expensive NAD(P)H cofactor. Undergraduate students in the PI?s laboratory have engineered hybrid P450 BM3 biocatalysts, which contain strategically positioned Ru(II)-diimine photosensitizers capable of delivering the necessary electrons to their active sites and sustaining photocatalytic activity. This approach circumvents the need for the redox partner enzymes and the NAD(P)H cofactor. The proposed work will utilize a three-pronged approach to improve the performance of the light-driven biocatalysts by 1) expanding the scope of their photocatalytic activity towards non-natural substrates, 2) enhancing their reusability, stability, and activity through immobilization, and 3) combining the approach with photoredox catalysis to expand C-H bond functionalization using visible light excitation.

The proposed research and educational objectives will keep engaging a diverse group of undergraduate students and teachers while enhancing their educational experiences at SJSU and beyond. Authentic research experiments will be integrated into a capstone biochemistry lab course to enrich student learning and train them for successful future careers in STEM fields. In addition, a summer workshop will be held for high school teachers to provide hands-on training and enable the implementation of light-driven experiments in their high-school classrooms.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merits:  

This project supported the development of efficient light-driven biocatalysts for the activation of molecular dioxygen and the selective oxyfunctionalization of various substrates towards the synthesis of useful synthetic building blocks upon visible light excitation. Biocatalytic processes are gaining increasing importance in organic synthesis from their unique selectivity advantages over traditional methods and has emerged as an important technology for meeting the demand for green and sustainable synthesis of various fine chemicals. Recently, the utilization of visible to drive biocatalytic processes has received great attention as a promising avenue for green catalysis.

The developed hybrid P450 enzymes exploit the photophysical properties of strategically positioned photosensitizers to deliver the necessary electrons to the enzyme active site and sustain catalysis upon visible light irradiation. This approach circumvents the need for additional redox partner enzymes or expensive cofactor.

We have utilized directed evolution to engineer the next generation of hybrid P450 enzymes with enhanced photocatalytic activity and broader substrate scope. The directed evolution approach is a recognized method for developing the next generation of biocatalysts and engineering unique properties. Hybrid mutants randomly generated displayed up to 10-fold improvement in photocatalytic activity. This enhanced activity was shown to be due to an increase in coupling efficiency between the electron delivery and the product formation.

In addition, we have been interested in immobilizing those biocatalysts. Like in a classical chemical process, working with heterogeneous catalysts enables their recovery and re-use, and in some cases enhance their catalytic efficiency. The cross-linking enzyme aggregates (CLEAs) approach offered a rapid and simple approach to develop and optimize heterogeneous P450 biocatalysts. We successfully developed new cross-linkers using various inorganic complexes bearing aldehyde functionalities to immobilize these enzymes. The heterogeneous biocatalysts showed high activity recovery compared to their counterpart in solution as well as reusability for several rounds of reactions.

As a major accomplishment, we successfully married the advantage of chemical catalysis with the selectivity of the hybrid biocatalysts by developing a light-driven chemoenzymatic approach to access various functionalized substituted arenes. This approach capitalized on the unique photoredox properties of the inorganic photosensitizers to initiate single electron transfer events. A range of oxyfunctionalized and trifluoromethylated arenes could be accessed using this approach.

Broader Impacts:

In addition to greatly involving undergraduate students in his research laboratory, the PI brought experiments related to the protein engineering of the light-driven biocatalysts into high school classrooms. We hosted several summer training workshops for local high school teachers and developed light-driven experiments and modular kits suitable for their own high school students. Participation in unique activities both in the research laboratory and in class settings has provided valuable training to students for successful careers in STEM fields.

This project resulted in 6 publications and 25 public presentations. The project supported the training of more than 25 undergraduate and 50 high school students during the project period.
